Javins v. First National Realty Corp., 4.raw_text: Javins v. First National Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970)
Javins v. First National Realty Corp., 4.proposition: See, e.g., Restatement (Second) of Property: Landlord & Tenant §§ 5.1, 12.1 (describing covenant of quiet enjoyment and landlord obligations); Javins v. First National Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970) (recognizing landlord obligations related to habitability and tenant remedies where premises uninhabitable).

Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.proposition: A landlord's failure to provide or promptly repair essential services such as hot water, when such failure substantially interferes with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises, may give rise to a claim for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and recoverable damages for interference, inconvenience, and out-of-pocket expenses incurred as a proximate result of the breach.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.support_reasoning: The decision is framed entirely in terms of an implied warranty of habitability and related contract remedies, not the covenant of quiet enjoyment. While the court explicitly allows recovery of rent, repair costs, and damages for discomfort and annoyance (e.g., inability to bathe due to inadequate hot water), it does so as elements of damages for breach of the implied warranty of habitability, not as a quiet enjoyment claim. The opinion mentions constructive eviction and quiet enjoyment historically but does not ground its holding or damages analysis in a covenant of quiet enjoyment theory.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.relevant_excerpt: “We also find persuasive the reasoning of some commentators that damages should be allowed for a tenant’s discomfort and annoyance arising from the landlord’s breach of the implied warranty of habitability. … [T]he residential tenant who has suffered a breach of the warranty . . . cannot bathe as frequently as he would like or at all if there is inadequate hot water… Thus, discomfort and annoyance are the common injuries caused by each breach and hence the true nature of the general damages the tenant is claiming.”

M.G.L. c. 186.proposition: Massachusetts statutes and regulations recognize and enforce basic habitability and sanitary standards for residential dwellings.

M.G.L. c. 111.proposition: Massachusetts statutes and regulations recognize and enforce basic habitability and sanitary standards for residential dwellings.

105 Code Mass. Regs. 410.000.proposition: Massachusetts statutes and regulations recognize and enforce basic habitability and sanitary standards for residential dwellings.

105 CMR 410.000.proposition: A landlord's failure to provide or promptly repair essential services such as hot water, when such failure substantially interferes with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises, may give rise to a claim for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and recoverable damages for interference, inconvenience, and out-of-pocket expenses incurred as a proximate result of the breach.

M.G.L. c. 111, \u00a7 127.proposition: A landlord's failure to provide or promptly repair essential services such as hot water, when such failure substantially interferes with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises, may give rise to a claim for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and recoverable damages for interference, inconvenience, and out-of-pocket expenses incurred as a proximate result of the breach.

M.G.L. c. 186 \u00a7\u00a7 1\u201340..proposition: Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 186 (Landlord and Tenant statutes), see generally M.G.L. c. 186 §§ 1–40.

M.G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7 127, et seq..proposition: Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 111, §§ 127, et seq. (public health and sanitary code enforcement).

M.G.L. c. 239.proposition: M.G.L. c. 239 (summary process and venue provisions; venue and landlord-tenant procedures).

M.G.L. c. 93A.proposition: M.G.L. c. 93A (Mass. Consumer Protection Act) (background authority for landlord obligations in consumer transactions — note: Plaintiff does not assert a separate c. 93A claim here but cites for general context).
